local_clues.clue: Refers to the appropriate way of keeping a slight arch in the lower back during a squat.

local_clues.quote: put a line straight up from the toes
local_clues.clue: Indicates the alignment of the knees, suggesting they should not go past the toes to avoid pressure on the knees.

local_clues.quote: going to go past that line
local_clues.clue: Reinforces that knee alignment is crucial to prevent knee damage during squats.

global_clues.quote: to doing a safe squat right
global_clues.clue: Emphasizes the importance of safety when performing squats.

global_clues.clue: Indicates the setup phase of preparing to squat.

logical_inferences.details: The repeated emphasis on knee alignment (LC2, LC3) suggests that ensuring the knees do not pass the toes is a key point of this segment. This aligns with the overarching goal of safe squatting (GC1).

local_clues.clue: Implies that correct form requires practice, especially when ensuring proper knee alignment.
Suggests starting with lighter or simulated weights to practice form before progressing to heavier weights.
A specific example of beginner practice techniques to focus on form before adding weight.

global_clues.quote: maintain that posture throughout the whole lift

global_clues.relevance_to_segment: Links the need for practice (LC1) and using lighter weights (LC2, LC3) to maintain proper posture as a foundational element of safe squatting.

logical_inferences.description: Importance of Practice with Light Weights
logical_inferences.details: The segment underlines the necessity of starting with lighter or dummy weights to perfect squat form (LC2, LC3), which correlates with the overall advice of maintaining posture throughout the lift (GC2).

local_clues.quote: not go past this plumb line

logical_inferences.details: Mentions of frequent form issues (LC2) and the consistent advice to keep the knees from going past the toes (LC1) suggest that improper knee alignment is a common and critical error addressed in this segment.
